description: An integer corresponding to a season of college basketball. CBBD's convention is to use the year in which the championship takes place, so if a game took place in the fall of 2024, the season would be recorded as "2025".
A string identifying the two years that one college basketball season spans, e.g. "20242025".
A unique identifier for each team.
The name of the team.
The conference the team plays in.
The number of games a team played.
The number of wins the team recorded.
The number of losses the team recorded.
The number of minutes a team played.
The number of possessions in games the team played in divided by the number of minutes played by the team, multiplied by 40 minutes.
The number of assists recorded by the team.
The number of blocks recorded by the team.
The number of steals recorded by the team.
The number of possessions recorded by the team.
An adjusted statistic that reflects a team's skill at shooting three-pointers, two-pointers, and free throws. For more details, see here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/True_shooting_percentage
A metric created by Dean Oliver to measure how many points per 100 possessions a team generates on offense. For more details, see here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Offensive_rating
The number of shots from the floor a team made.
The number of shots from the floor a team attempted.
The number of field goals made divided by the number of field goals attempted.
The number of two-point shots a team made.
The number of two-point shots a team attempted.
The number of two-point shots a team made divded by the number of two-point shots they attempted.
The number of three-point shots a team made.
The number of three-point shots a team attempted.
The number of three-point shots a team made divided by the number of three-point shots they attempted.
The number of free throw shots a team made.
The number of free throw shots a team attempted.
The number of free throw shots a team made divded by the number of free throw shots they attempted.
The number of offensive rebounds a team recorded.
The number of defensive rebounds a team recorded.
The total number of rebounds a team recorded, offensive and defensive.
How many turnovers the team committed.
How many team turnovers the team committed. This includes turnovers like dead-ball turnovers.
How many fouls the team committed.
How many technical fouls the team committed.
How many flagrant fouls the team committed.
The number of points the  team scored.
The number of points the team recorded scoring in the paint.
The number of points the team recorded off turnovers by the opposing team.
The number of points the team recorded on fast breaks.

An adjusted statistic that reflects the value of three-pointers relative to all other baskets by weighing three points more, representing a team's shooting efficiency. For more details, see here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Effective_field_goal_percentage
The number of free throws a team attempted divded by the number of field goals a team attempted. This metric is commonly used to evaluate a team's ability to draw personal fouls.
The number of assists a team records divided by the number of turnovers they commit. This metric is commonly used to evaluate the accuracy of a team's passing.

An estimate of the rate at which a team secured offensive reboulds, measured as OREB / the total number of balls that a team could have rebounded. For more details, see here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rebound_rate
The number of assists recorded by the team's opponent.
The number of blocks recorded by the team's opponent.
The number of steals recorded by the team's opponent.
The number of possessions recorded by the team's opponent.
An adjusted statistic that reflects a team's skill at shooting three-pointers, two-pointers, and free throws. For more details, see here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/True_shooting_percentage
A metric created by Dean Oliver to measure how many points per 100 possessions a team generates on offense. For more details, see here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Offensive_rating
The number of shots from the floor a team made.
The number of shots from the floor a team attempted.
The number of field goals made divided by the number of field goals attempted.
The number of two-point shots a team made.
The number of two-point shots a team attempted.
The number of two-point shots a team made divded by the number of two-point shots they attempted.
The number of three-point shots a team made.
The number of three-point shots a team attempted.
The number of three-point shots a team made divided by the number of three-point shots they attempted.
The number of free throw shots a team made.
The number of free throw shots a team attempted.
The number of free throw shots a team made divded by the number of free throw shots they attempted.
The number of offensive rebounds a team recorded.
The number of defensive rebounds a team recorded.
The total number of rebounds a team recorded, offensive and defensive.
How many turnovers the team's opponent committed.
How many team turnovers the team's opponent committed. This includes turnovers like dead-ball turnovers.
How many fouls the team's opponent committed.
How many technical fouls the team's opponent committed.
How many flagrant fouls the team's opponent committed.
The number of points the  team scored.
The number of points the team's opponent recorded scoring in the paint.
The number of points the team's opponent recorded off turnovers by the opposing team.
The number of points the team's opponent recorded on fast breaks.

An adjusted statistic that reflects the value of three-pointers relative to all other baskets by weighing three points more, representing a team's shooting efficiency. For more details, see here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Effective_field_goal_percentage
The number of free throws a team attempted divded by the number of field goals a team attempted. This metric is commonly used to evaluate a team's ability to draw personal fouls.
The number of assists a team records divided by the number of turnovers they commit. This metric is commonly used to evaluate the accuracy of a team's passing.

An estimate of the rate at which a team secured offensive reboulds, measured as OREB / the total number of balls that a team could have rebounded. For more details, see here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rebound_rate
